sentences: Abdurauf Fitrat (sometimes spelled Abdulrauf Fitrat or Abdurrauf Fitrat, Uzbek: Abdurauf Fitrat / Абдурауф Фитрат; 1886 – 4 October 1938) was an Uzbek author, journalist and politician in Central Asia under Russian and Soviet rule.
Fitrat initially composed poems in the Persian language, but switched to a puristic Turkic tongue by 1917.
Fitrat was responsible for the change to Uzbek as Bukhara's national language in 1921, before returning to writing texts in Tajik later during the 1920s.
Fitrat was responsible for the change to Uzbek as Bukhara's national language in 1921, before returning to writing texts in Tajik later during the 1920s.
In the late 1920s, Fitrat took part in the efforts for Latinization of Uzbek and Tajik.
Fitrat was influenced by his studies in Istanbul during the early 1910s, where he came into contact with Islamic reformism.
After the end of the emirate, Fitrat accepted several posts in the government of the Bukharan People's Soviet Republic, before he was forced to spend a year in Russia.
During Stalin's Great Purge, Fitrat was arrested and prosecuted for counter-revolutionary and nationalist activities, and finally executed in 1938.
After his death, his work was banned for decades.
Fitrat was rehabilitated in 1956, yet critical evaluation of his work has changed several times since.

Fitrat's name has a number of variation across forms and transliterations: He mostly went by the pen name Fitrat (فطرت‎‎ Fiṭrat, also transcribed as Fetrat or, according to the Uzbek spelling reform of 1921, Pitrat).

sentences: An issue is the disappearance of at least ten of Fitrat's works and the unclear dating of others, for example of Muqaddas qon, which was written sometime between 1917 and 1924.
section: == Work analysis == | === Statistical and thematical developments ===

sentences: There are different dates for Munozara as well, but according to Hisao Komatsu Allworth's dating of 1327 AH (1911/1912) can be called "convincing".
section: == Work analysis == | === Statistical and thematical developments ===

sentences: There are different dates for Munozara as well, but according to Hisao Komatsu Allworth's dating of 1327 AH (1911/1912) can be called "convincing".
section: == Work analysis == | === Statistical and thematical developments ===

sentences: However, in 1917 he changed over to a highly purist Turki, in which he even explained some words in footnotes.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: In an article titled Tilimiz ("Our language") of 1919 Fitrat called the Uzbek language the "unhappiest language of the world".
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: In these days, Fitrat denied that Persian was one of Central Asia's native languages.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: In Bedil (1923), a bilingual work with passages in Persian and Turkic, Fitrat presents an Uzbek tongue influencesd by the Ottoman language as a counterpart to the traditional Persian poetic language, and therefore as a language suited for modernization.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: His partial return to Tajik during the 1920s can, according to Borjian, be ascribed to the end of Jadidism and the beginning of the suppression of Turkish nationalisms.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: Therefore, the creation of the Tajik SSR in 1929, out of the Tajik ASSR which had been a part of the Uzbek SSR, "may" (Borjian) have motivated Fitrat to return to writing in Tajik.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: After 1923, in Turkestan a reformed Arabic alphabet with better identification of vowels came into use; however, it still could not accommodate the variety of vowels in the Turkic languages.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: Fitrat "obviously" (William Fierman) did not interpret the Arabic alphabet as holy or as an important part of Islam: Already in 1921 during a congress in Tashkent, he argued in favour of abolishing all forms of the Arabic letters apart from the initial form.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: The demand to harmonize the orthography of foreign words according to the rules of vowel harmony was implemented in Bukhara and the ASSR Turkestan in 1923, even though many dialects did not know this differentiation.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: Until 1929, the alphabets of the Central Asian Turkic languages were Latinized.
section: == Work analysis == | === Language and script ===

sentences: In Fitrat's oeuvre a series of nonfiction and educational publications can be found: Rohbari najot ("The leader towards deliverance", 1916), for example, is an ethical treatise supporting the jadidist reforms with citations from the Quran.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: In the anthologies Eng eski turkiy adabiyot namunalari ("Examples from the oldest Turkic literature", 1927) and Oʻzbek adabiyoti namunalari ("Examples of Uzbek literature", 1928), which were directed at more advanced students, Fitrat strongly diverged from the Communist line on nationality politics by denying a strict segregation between "pure Uzbek" literature and Central Asian literature in general.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: In the anthologies Eng eski turkiy adabiyot namunalari ("Examples from the oldest Turkic literature", 1927) and Oʻzbek adabiyoti namunalari ("Examples of Uzbek literature", 1928), which were directed at more advanced students, Fitrat strongly diverged from the Communist line on nationality politics by denying a strict segregation between "pure Uzbek" literature and Central Asian literature in general.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: ("What should we do about the old schools?", 1927) brought him the attention of the GPU.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: Other noteworthy nonfiction publications are Adabiyot qoidalari ("Theory of literature", 1926) and Fors shoiri Umar Hayyom ("The Persian poet Omar Khayyam", 1929).
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: Other noteworthy nonfiction publications are Adabiyot qoidalari ("Theory of literature", 1926) and Fors shoiri Umar Hayyom ("The Persian poet Omar Khayyam", 1929).
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: In 1923 Fitrat entrusted Viktor Uspensky to record the entire Bukharan shashmaqam, but without the original texts which, to the greatest extent, were in Persian.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: A version of the Bukharan shashmaqam written by the composer Yunus Rajabiy in 1930 by order of Fitrat was based on Uzbek poetry and became popular more than thirty years later.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: A version of the Bukharan shashmaqam written by the composer Yunus Rajabiy in 1930 by order of Fitrat was based on Uzbek poetry and became popular more than thirty years later.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: Oʻzbek klassik musiqasi va uning tarixi („Uzbek classical music and its history“, 1927) fabricated the basis of a national musicology.
section: == Work analysis == | === Nonfiction ===

sentences: In Shaytonning tangriga isyoni ("Satan's rebellion against God", 1924), Fitrat was one of the first Turki poets to use Turkic suffixes for tail rhymes, along the usual internal rhymes.
section: == Work analysis == | === Poetry ===

sentences: In 1918, Fitrat introduced the critique of the Perso-Arabic system of prosody called aruz from Istanbul to Central Asia and demanded, together with others, the provision for Turkic metrics in Turkic poetry and the use of the meter called barmoq.
section: == Work analysis == | === Poetry ===

sentences: Allworth recognizes four different types of dialogue and drama in Fitrat's work: Discussions with strangers (1911-1913, for example in Munozara and Bayonoti sayyohi hindi), counseling with heroes from the past (1915-1919, Muqaddas qon and Temurning sogʻonasi), allegorical dialogue (1920-1924, for example in Qiyomat and Shaytonning tangriga isyoni), and dialectic (1926-1934, in Toʻlqin).
section: == Work analysis == | === Drama ===

sentences: In 1983, still before Fitrat's reinterpretation during perestroika, Ahmad Aliev recognized an "unconventional complexity" in Fitrat's dramatic work.
section: == Work analysis == | ==== Dramas of ambiguity ====

sentences: According to Edward A. Allworth Fitrat's dramas from the years between 1922 and 1924 - especially Qiyomat, Bedil and Shaytonning tangriga isyoni - are marked by subtleties and intended ambiguities.
section: == Work analysis == | ==== Dramas of ambiguity ====

sentences: According to Edward A. Allworth Fitrat's dramas from the years between 1922 and 1924 - especially Qiyomat, Bedil and Shaytonning tangriga isyoni - are marked by subtleties and intended ambiguities.
section: == Work analysis == | ==== Dramas of ambiguity ====

sentences: The historical drama Abulfayzxon ("Abulfaiz Khan", last ruler of the Bukharan Janid dynasty of the Uzbek Khanate, 1924) draws parallels between historical and contemporary upheaval and absolutisms in Bukhara and is held as first Uzbek tragedy.
section: == Work analysis == | ==== Dramas of ambiguity ====

sentences: Like Abdulla Qodiriy and Gʻafur Gʻulom, Fitrat increasingly used satiric concepts in his stories from the 1920s onwards.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===

sentences: Only a few years earlier, prose had started gaining ground in Central Asia; by including satirical elements, reformers like Fitrat succeeded in winning over the audience.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===

sentences: After 1920, the "victims" of Fitrat's satire, besides mistaken ideologues and cumbersome bureaucrats, also included the Soviet rulers.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===

sentences: Similarities to Nasreddin stories can be found in several of Fitrat's texts, for example in Munozara, Qiyomat and  Oq mozor ("The white Tomb", 1928), even though the actual Nasreddin figure is missing in the last text.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===

sentences: Qiyomat was first reworked in 1935, which led to the loss of contemporary references; Fitrat transferred the story into the time of Tsarist rule.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===

sentences: In the Soviet versions, the focus of the story is no longer on the colonial oppression of the Tsarist era and the satiric presentation of life in the Soviet Union, but on the criticism of religion.
section: == Work analysis == | === Satire and Nasreddinic figures ===
